The '''2011 Lebanese protests''' have been seen as influenced by the [[Arab Spring]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71Q08L20110227 | work=Reuters | title=Lebanese protest against sectarian political system | date=27 February 2011}}</ref> The main protests focused on calls for political reform especially against [[Confessionalism (politics)|confessionalism]] in [[Lebanon]].
== Background == === Political system === [[Lebanon]] is a [[parliamentary republic]] within the overall framework of [[Confessionalism (politics)|confessionalism]], a form of [[consociationalism]] in which the highest offices are proportionately reserved for representatives from certain religious communities. The [[Constitution of Lebanon|constitution]] grants the people the right to change their government, however, from the mid-1970s until the parliamentary elections in 1992, a [[Lebanese civil war|civil war]] precluded the exercise of political rights. According to the constitution, direct elections must be held for the parliament every 4 years. The last parliamentary [[Lebanese general election, 2009|election]] was in 2009,<ref>[http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/pro-western-coalition-declares-victory-in-lebanon/article1172689/ Pro-Western coalition declares victory in Lebanon - The Globe and Mail]</ref> which led to about six months before a new government was formed. The [[Parliament of Lebanon|parliament]], in turn, elects a [[List of Presidents of Lebanon|president]] every 6 years to a single term, he is, however, not eligible for re-election. The last presidential [[Lebanese presidential election, 2008|election]] was in 2008. The president and parliament choose the [[List of Prime Ministers of Lebanon|prime minister]]. [[List of political parties in Lebanon|Political parties]] are grouped with either the [[March 8 alliance]] or the [[March 14 alliance]]. (the [[Progressive Socialist Party]] of [[Walid Jumblatt]] is ostensibly independent but leans towards March 8 since their withdrawal from the then governing March 14).
Lebanon [[Demographics of Lebanon|demographics]] is roughly split amongst [[Sunni]]s, [[Shia]]s and [[Christianity in Lebanon|Christians]] (most of whom are [[Maronite]]). Due to the demographic concerns, amid fears the country could be a [[powder keg]], a [[census]] has not been carried out since 1932. Since then the government has only published rough estimates of the population.<ref>http://www.country-studies.com/lebanon/population.html</ref>
=== 2011 new government === {{main|Lebanese government of November 2009}} On January 12, 2011, the government collapsed after Energy Minister [[Gebran Bassil]] announced that all ten opposition ministers had resigned following months of warnings by Hezbollah that it would not remain inactive should there be indictments against the group by the [[Special Tribunal for Lebanon]] in the assassination of former Prime Minister [[Rafic Hariri]].<ref name="BBC collapse">{{cite news|title=Hezbollah and allies topple Lebanese unity government|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12170608|accessdate=12 January 2011|newspaper=BBC|date=12 January 2011}}</ref> Preliminary indictments were issued January 17 as expected,<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011115181151959973.html Hariri indictments set for Monday - Middle East - Al Jazeera English<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>) President [[Michel Suleiman]]'s appointed Minister of State, [[Adnan Sayyed Hussein]],<ref name="NYT collapse">{{cite news|last=Bakri|first=Nada|title=Resignations Deepen Crisis for Lebanon|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/13/world/middleeast/13lebanon.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1|accessdate=12 January 2011|newspaper=New York Times|date=12 January 2011}}</ref> resigned later bringing the total number of ministers who quit to 11 thus causing the fall of the government. The ''New York Times'' suggested that the resignations came after the collapse of talks between Syria and Saudi Arabia to ease tensions in Lebanon. The resignations stemmed from PM Hariri's refusal to call an emergency cabinet session over discussion for withdrawing cooperation with the STL.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news| url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/01/14/stories/2011011467772400.htm | location=Chennai, India | work=The Hindu | title=Lebanese government falls | date=14 January 2011}}</ref><ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011117171436837590.html US welcomes Hariri indictment - Middle East - Al Jazeera English<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Suleiman, who is constitutionally responsible for the formation of a new government, accepted the resignations saying: "In line with clause one of article 69 in the [[Constitution of Lebanon|Lebanese constitution]] on the circumstances under which the government is considered to have resigned...as the government has lost more than one third of its members...the cabinet [is requested to] act as a caretaker government until the formation of a new government."<ref name="almanarreactions2">"http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=169956&language=en</ref> The March 8 alliance then nominate [[Najib Mikati]] to form a government in line with the accepted norms that a prime minister must be a Sunni (even though most Sunnis are supporters of March 14).
On 13 June, a new government was [[Lebanese government of June 2011|formed]].
== Protests == === 27 February === {{Expand section|date=March 2011}} {{External media | video1 = {{YouTube|aIRjkcRPboY|Hundreds of Demonstrators Call for Revolution in Lebanon}} }} On 27 February, hundreds of [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] marched along the old demarcation line{{Clarify|date=March 2011}} in the capital [[Beirut]] against the country's sectarian [[Politics of Lebanon|political system]]. A peaceful sit-in in [[Sidon|Saida]] also took place.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71Q08L20110227 |title=Lebanese protest against sectarian political system |publisher=Af.reuters.com |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=6 March 2011}}</ref>
===6 March=== In follow-up rallies to the 27 February demonstration, around 8,000 people marched from Dora to Beirut in the second round of a campaign to "topple the sectarian regime" and its leading symbols and to call for a secular state. Similar protests took place in [[Baalbek]] and [[Sidon]].<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=1&categ_id=2&article_125693#axzz1G0xiKbQd</ref>
===13 March=== A rally was organised by the [[March 14 alliance]] in which several hundreds of thousands supporters attended in commemoration of the start [[Cedar Revolution]] 6 years earlier. The main slogan of the rally was calling for the disarmament of [[Hezbollah]] and to renew support for the ideals of the revolution.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=1&categ_id=2&article_id=125927#axzz1GUpYlbcn</ref>
===20 March=== Thousands of Lebanese took to the streets to protest against the sectarian nature of the governing system.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/03/lebanon-politics-women-middle-east-sectarian-.html | work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> This was the third protest against the [[Politics of Lebanon|sectarian political system]].
===15 May=== Ten pro Palestinian protestors were reportedly killed by Israeli soldiers during rallies taking place in [[Maroun al-Ras]] village [[2011 Israeli border demonstrations#15 May|to commemorate the Palestinian Nakba Day]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yalibnan.com/2011/05/15/lebanese-condemn-israeli-agression-against-protesters/#more-24963|title=Lebanese condemn Israeli agression against protesters|publisher=yalibnan.com|date=15 May 2011 |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
===17 June=== [[File:Lebanese army convoy.jpg|thumb|Lebanese army convoy patrolling Jabal Mahsen, a few weeks after the 2011 clashes]] Seven people were killed and and 59 were wounded in Tripoli, on Friday, June 17. Armed clashes erupted in following a rally in support of [[2011 Syrian uprising|Syrian protesters]]. Fighting broke out between gunmen positioned in the rival neighborhoods of Jabal Mohsen (mainly [[Alawites]] who support the Syrian regime) and Bab al-Tabbaneh (mainly Sunnis, supporting the Syrian uprising). Among the dead were a Lebanese army soldier and an official from the Alawite [[Arab Democratic Party (Lebanon)|Arab Democratic Party]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=282966 |title=Clashes in Lebanonâs Tripoli leave six dead |publisher=nowlebanon.com|date=17 June 2011 |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2011/Jun-22/Arrest-warrants-issued-over-Tripoli-clashes.ashx#axzz1Q6NT1BXT |title=Arrest warrants issued over Tripoli clashes |publisher=www.dailystar.com.lb|date=22 June 2011 |accessdate=23 June 2011}}</ref>
=== 26 June === On 26 June, hundreds of people marched towards the parliament in Beirut demanding the end of Lebanon's confessional system.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nowlebanon.com/NewsArticleDetails.aspx?ID=285787|title=Rally for secularism commences in Beirut |publisher=www.nowlebanon.com|date=26 June 2011 |accessdate=26 June 2011}}</ref>
===12 October=== What the local press considered might be the largest general strike in it's history had been called for this date. <ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Politics/2011/Oct-11/150985-largest-general-strike-looms.ashx#axzz1aThgEQqg</ref> The General Labor Confederation is demanding higher wages, among other things. The cabinet acceded to these demands,<ref>http://www.lebanonews.net/mainhl.asp?hlid=8156</ref> and the marches were "suspended. However, the teacher's union refused to accept this, went on strike anyway, and paralyzed the nation's education system<ref>http://www.lebanonews.net/mainhl.asp?hlid=8158</ref>
== Spillover from Syria == On 5 and 6 October, the Syrian army invaded killing one person before retreating back across the border, causing instability in the Mikati government.<ref>http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Local-News/2011/Oct-07/150658-march-8-mps-slam-local-reaction-to-incursion-by-sisterly-state.ashx#axzz1a2i2LdCB</ref> âI am not being silent about this, we are dealing with the issue normally,â Mikati said, noting the permeability of the border.
